subSections.title: Alternative forms
subSections.text: * In {{w|traditional Chinese}} (based on the modern character forms used in {{w|zh:國字標準字體|Taiwan}} and {{w|zh:常用字字形表|Hong Kong}}), the bottom left component is {{l|mul|朮}} ({{l|mul|𣎳}} with an additional dot at its top right corner). * In mainland China (based on the {{w|Xin Zixing}} ({{w2|zh|新字形}}) standardized character forms), the bottom left component is {{l|mul|朩}} instead which is one stroke less. * In Korean {{w|hanja}}, the bottom left component is {{l|mul|术}}, which is also the historical form found in the {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}. * In Japanese {{w|shinjitai}} and Vietnamese [[Nôm]], the bottom left component is {{l|mul|木}} which is one stroke less. * Three {{w|CJK Compatibility Ideographs}} exist for this character: ** U+F970 corresponds to the Japanese {{w|kyūjitai}} form containing {{l|mul|术}} which is similar to the historical Kangxi form. ** U+FA96 corresponds to the alternative Korean form which is similar to the Japanese {{w|shinjitai}} form containing {{l|mul|木}}. ** U+2F8F5 is similar to the traditional form in Taiwan but has {{l|mul|𣎳}} (without dot at top right corner) instead of {{l|mul|朮}} as its bottom left component.

subSections.title: Han character
subSections.text: {{Han char|rn=79|rad=殳|as=07|asmj+=06|sn=11|snmj+=10|four=47947|canj=KCHNE,KDHNE|ids=⿰⿱㐅朩殳(G),⿰⿱㐅朮殳(HT),⿰⿱㐅木殳(JV,U+FA96),⿰⿱㐅术殳(K,U+F970).⿰⿱㐅𣎳殳(U+2F8F5)}}

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}

In the oracle bone script, it was an {{Han compound|戈||t1=spear|t2=hair|ls=ic|nocap=y}} – a man impaled in the head.

In the bronze script, {{zh-l|*人|man}} was added under the hair to accentuate the killing of the man. In some bronze inscriptions, {{zh-l|*殳|spear}} or {{zh-l|*攴}} was used in place of {{lang|zh|戈}}.

In the bamboo and silk script, symbol representing the man being killed corrupted into {{zh-l|*杀}}: {{Han compound|乂|t1=weapon for killing|𣎳}}. The seal script inherits this: {{Han compound|𣏂|c1=p|殳|c2=s|t2=spear|ls=psc}}.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text:
* Normally, the subject of 殺 should at least be alive. The sentence "A tiger killed many people." can be validly translated as {{lang|zh|老虎殺死數人}}, while the sentence "This accident killed many people." is seldom translated as *{{lang|zh|這次事故殺死數人}}. For death caused by non-living things, split forms of {{zh-l|致死}} are often used instead:
*: {{zh-x|這 次 事故 '''致''' 數 人 '''死亡'''。|This accident '''caused''' many people's '''death'''.}}
